title: Vulnerabilities in exported activity WebView

activities.message:
### Update Fix
Change the activity to android:exported="false"
Possible this article will help you:
https://pentestlab.blog/2017/02/12/android-webview-vulnerabilities

Hi @shell_c0de , 

We managed to validate this issue, but not all the exploits have worked. However, I managed to close the app using your exploit, and that should be enough to triage it. For the LFI, I got a message back with an error. Also, the phising may have worked. 

Thanks, 
@ktistai

Hi @ktistai ,

If LFI gives an error, try reinstalling the Shipt application and launching it. Next, run HunterExploit and click on the "LFI" button.
The error may be related to the configuration for testing or the pushio_store.xml file may be missing
Try to read another file via adb:
`adb shell am start -n com.shipt.groceries/com.pushio.manager.iam.ui.PushIOMessageViewActivity -a "android.intent.action.VIEW" --es "url" "file:///data/data/com.shipt.groceries/shared_prefs/com.google.android.gms.appid.xml" --es "type" "alert"`
My configuration:
Android 8.1.1
com.shipt.groceries
Version: 1.42.0
###Fix
To prevent application files from being read via WebView
Specify the following setting
```java
WebView.getSettings().SetAllowFileAccess(false);
```
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/WebSettings#setAllowFileAccess(boolean)

Thanks, 
@shell_c0de

Hi @ktistai ,
Can I expect a bounty in the near future?

I apologize for the delay in this response @shell_c0de. Just to confirm, remote exploitation would require an end user do 2 things: 1.) Render their device configuration in an insecure state (allowing external app downloads) and 2.) Download and install a malicious application.  Otherwise, physical access to the device is required by the attacker. If these are the facts, we are going to rate this a low-risk vulnerability. With that said, we are engaging development teams to confirm whether or not this setting can/will be changed. I will update the report when we come to a conclusion.

Hi @shiptsecurity1  ,

You're right. An attacker needs a device with a popular configuration that you specified 1), 2).
Nevertheless, I indicated in the CVSS v3.0 calculator the attack vector local.
Your policy does not indicate anything about the restrictions on the use of an exploit through local access. I hope for understanding and fair bounty.

Thanks, 
@shell_c0de
Also, malicious applications can be distributed through Google Play.

It follows from this that clauses 1), 2) are desirable for an attacker, but not necessary. In addition, the malicious application does not require administrator rights or any privileges. You need to send only one intent.
As a confirmation of the presence of malicious applications on Google Play, I will cite sources:
http://www.securitynewspaper.com/2018/02/08/android-malware-problem-google-removed-700000-malicious-apps-play-store-2017/
https://www.symantec.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/hidden-app-malware-google-play

@shell_c0de, @ktistai , I am still looking in to this to see what can actually be done, but we have had this clause in our policy for some time and before you submitted this bug, so to say we don't have 'any restrictions' on this is not accurate `* Self XSS or XSS that affects only out-of-date browsers or devices that require the user to configure them in an insecure state (allowing installation of applications from untrusted sources).`.  With that said, this is being tested and if we're making a code change, we will award a bounty.
Also, attack complexity is definitely high for this one and I have adjusted accordingly.
@shell_c0de, if we set `android:exported="false"` per your suggestion, then the android system wouldn't even be able to launch our application. Isn't that correct?

Also, I believe this is implemented per Oracle's documentation for this SDK (https://docs.oracle.com/cloud/latest/marketingcs_gs/OMCFB/android/in-app-msg/), but still having engineering verify that. 
```
  <activity android:name="com.pushio.manager.iam.ui.PushIOMessageViewActivity"
    android:theme="@android:style/Theme.Translucent.NoTitleBar">

    <intent-filter>
        <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />
        <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
        <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />
        <data android:scheme="pio-YOUR_API_KEY" />
    </intent-filter>

   </activity>
```

Hi @shiptsecurity1 ,

I agree with your decision to lower the threat of vulnerability to the medium level.

If you set `exported="false"` the activity will not accept the intent from external applications. Thus, attacker will not be able to launch WebView. In this case, you can violate the functionality of the application if the Intent is to be sent from an external application.

A possible solution would be to check the URL in the class `PushIOMessageViewActivity` for example host or scheme (`file://`,`chrome://`,`javascript`). You need to choose the most appropriate verification method for WebView suitable for your case.

Thanks, 
@shell_c0de
From which application the Intent is sent to the class `PushIOMessageViewActivity`?

###Fix
Replace the `PushIOManager.aar` library
```java
<Project_Name>/app/libs/PushIOManager.aar //old version
<Project_Name>/app/libs/PushIOManager.aar //6.39.1 Fix version
```

https://github.com/pushio/PushIOManager_Android/blob/master/PushIOManager.aar

Hi @shiptsecurity1 , @ktistai 

Any update?
Vulnerability is still reproduce.
To fix it, you need to update the PushIOManager library.

Regards, 
@shell_c0de

Thank you for your report @shell_c0de and I apologize for the delay. Our engineering team is still making decisions regarding the continued use of the Responsys product, but I am paying a bounty as this is a valid vulnerability. I have forwarded the relevant information to the engineering team as well and will update you with our final decision. Thanks again for you report and patience.
Thank. I wait for fixed issue.

Update: Our engineering team is upgrading to the newest version of the Responsys service and will update the libraries then. Will keep you posted on the progress @shell_c0de. Thanks again for your patience.

@shell_c0de , I apologize for the delay. A few weeks ago we updated Responsys to latest SDK and the changes are released to 100% of our users in 1.57 app version. Can you verify that it has been remediated?
We believe this has been resolved. Requesting retest.

Hi @shiptsecurity1, @ktistai,
Full disclosure, please?

Kind regards,
@shell_c0de

summaries.content:
A vulnerability was identified in `com.pushio.manager.iam.ui.PushIOMessageViewActivity` exported activity of an Oracle library, allowing to open arbitrary links in WebView without scheme validation.
After reporting to Oracle, a patch was released for the library. After that Shipt promptly replaced the library, fixing the vulnerability.
